awd_titl_txt: Umpolung Reactivity in Stereoselective Synthesis of 2-Deoxy Glycosides and Thioglycosides
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jianglong Zhu of the Department of Chemistry at University of Toledo will develop umpolung reactivity-based glycosylations for stereoselective syntheses of biologically important 2-deoxy glycosides and thioglycosides.  Despite recent accomplishments in the development of glycosylation methodology, stereoselective synthesis of 2-deoxy sugars remains challenging because of the lack of a directing group at the C-2 position.  This project focuses on investigating reactions of stereochemically defined 2-deoxy glycosyl anions with sugar-derived peroxo and disulfide acceptors for stereoselective preparation of 2-deoxy glycosides and thioglycosides.  In addition, experimental efforts will be taken to understand the mechanism of these umpolung reactivity-based glycosylations. 

Successful accomplishment of this project will have a significant impact on synthetic organic community, because it will provide a strategy that complements current methods in the stereoselective synthesis of structurally challenging and biologically valuable 2-deoxy glycosides and thioglycosides.  This project could lead to the synthesis of a variety of sugar based therapeutic agents.  In addition, it will provide excellent training for undergraduate and graduate students, K-12 science teachers, and high school students, including those from groups currently underrepresented in the chemical sciences.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Under the support of this NSF grant, we have developed several new umpolung reactivity-based glycosylation methods for stereoselective synthesis of both O- and S-linked 2-deoxy oligosaccharides/glycosides: 1) stereoselective synthesis of both α- and β-S-linked 2-deoxy oligosaccharides/glycosides via sulfenylation of stereochemically defined 2-deoxy glycosyl lithium species with sugar-derived disulfide acceptors (Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2013, 52, 8012 –8016; Synlett 2014, 25, 308-312); 2) stereoselective synthesis of 2-deoxy-β-glycosides via anomeric O-alkylation (J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 3172-3175); 3) stereoselective synthesis of α-digitoxosides and α-boivinosides via chelation-controlled anomeric O-alkylation (J. Carbohydr. Chem. 2014, 33, 438-451). In addition, based on the glycosylation methods we developed, we have accomplished: 1) synthesis of antitumor antibiotic derhodinosylurdamycin A (Chem. Eur. J. 2015, 21, 13553-13557); 2) synthesis of 2-deoxy trisaccharide glycal of antitumor antibiotics landomycins A and E (Carbohydr. Res. 2016, 430, 54-58); 3) stereoselective synthesis of S-linked hexasaccharide of landomycin A (Org. Lett. 2015, 17, 4530-4533); 4) synthesis of S-linked trisaccharide analog of derhodinosylurdamycin A (unpublished). Furthermore, the sugar-derived triflate acceptors prepared under support of this NSF grant have been utilized for the development of new β-mannopyranosylation via anomeric O-alkylation (Angew. Chem., Int. Ed. 2016, 55, 4767-4771).

 

Under the support of this NSF grant, the PI has given 12 invited oral presentations at eight universities as well as regional and national meetings/symposiums. The research results have also been disseminated to the community by the PI and his group members via a total of 19 oral and poster presentations in the regional and national meetings/symposiums. In addition, under the support of this NSF grant, eight peer-reviewed articles have been published and an additional one manuscript is in preparation. Four PhD dissertations were also generated from the support of this NSF grant.

 

This research will have significant impact on medicinal chemistry and glycobiology. 2-Deoxy sugars are an important class of carbohydrates which exist in numerous biologically active natural products and clinical agents. These sugar subunits play critical roles in their biological activity as well as stability and solubility. It is also known that the glycosidic linkage of 2-deoxy glycosides is susceptible to hydrolysis in acid media or by glycosyl hydrolases. We have developed new umpolung-type chemical methods which will enable stereoselective synthesis of both natural O-linked 2-deoxy sugars and unnatural “non-hydrolyzable” S-linked 2-deoxy sugars in sufficient quantities for comparative studies of their chemical, physical, and biological properties. In addition, S-linked “non-hydrolyzable” 2-deoxy sugars may be potentially used as tools for studying glycobiology. The ultimate goal of this research is to discover effective therapeutic agents.

 

Under the support of this NSF grant, seven female high school students from financially disadvantaged families or underrepresented groups (four of them were also supported by ACS Project Seed program), one high school teacher (also supported by UT IMAGINE 2 Program), eight undergraduate students, six graduate students, and one female visiting assistant professor were offered opportunity to actively participate in this research. It is anticipated that those research experiences will impact their career development in the future. Most of those high school students continued their next-level education in chemistry or related programs in college. The high school teacher has incorporated his experience into the classroom for training the next generation scientists. Some undergraduate students are pursuing their PharmD/PhD or MD in medical schools, while some are planning to. Four graduate students earned their PhD degree and three of them are working as postdoctoral researchers at various institutions while one of them is working in industry. Two graduate students are currently pursuing their Ph.D. degree under the supervision of the PI. In addition, a female visiting assistant professor co-authored three publications with the PI and pursued her independent career as a tenure-track assistant professor of chemistry.

 

The PI participated in teaching an undergraduate course “CHEM 1910, Introduction to Research” and talked about “Chemical synthesis of antitumor antibiotics bearing 2-deoxy sugars” in the spring of 2013-2016 to help undergraduate student recognize the importance of chemical science. Besides, the PI pursued outreach efforts in Summer 2012-2016, such as: 1) The University of Toledo Summer 2012 SMET EXCEL designed to prepare students who are members of groups underrepresented in higher education for success in college and increase their self-esteem, cultural awareness of diversity, and civic involvement and responsibility; 2) The University of Toledo Summer 2012 Latino Youth Summit Overnight (LYSO) which is designed to attract Latino youth to pursue university education in the science and technology. In addition, in the spring of 2013-2015, the PI participated in science/engineering course offered at University of Toledo and via distance learning at sites throughout Ohio to improve pre-K–12 STEM education and teacher development.


Last Modified: 09/05/2016
Modified by: Jianglong Zhu
